title: George Smith (MP for Exeter)
text:
Sir George Smith (died 21 March 1619) of Madworthy-juxta-Exeter and Madford House, Exeter, Devon, was a merchant who served as <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament">MP</a> for <a href="Exeter%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Exeter</a> in 1604, was three times Mayor of Exeter and was Exeter's richest citizen, possessing 25 <a href="Manorialism">manor</a>s. He was the grandfather of <a href="George%20Monck%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Albemarle">George Monck, 1st Duke of Albemarle</a> (1608-1670) <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Garter">KG</a> and of <a href="John%20Grenville%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Bath">John Grenville, 1st Earl of Bath</a> (1628–1701).
Origins.
He was the eldest son of John Smith (died pre 1581) of Borage (or "Burridge"), near Tiverton, a merchant who served as Sheriff of Exeter in 1565 and <a href="Mayor%20of%20Exeter">Mayor of Exeter</a> in 1567/8, by his wife Alice Muttleberry, daughter of Alexander Muttleberry of Jordans, Somerset.
Career.
He rebuilt his Exeter <a href="townhouse%20%28Great%20Britain%29">townhouse</a> in 1584 at a cost of £1,000. His mercantile activities included dealing in tin, a noted product of Cornwall, and he invested in the colonizing voyage to North America undertaken by Sir Humphrey Gilbert in 1583.
He was Sheriff of Exeter for 1583–84 and <a href="Mayor%20of%20Exeter">Mayor of Exeter</a> for 1586–87, 1597–98 and 1607–08. He was knighted at <a href="Greenwich">Greenwich</a> on 12 June 1604.
Marriages and children.
George Smith married twice:
Death and burial.
He died on 21 March 1619 and was buried in Exeter Cathedral. His heir was his son Sir Nicholas Smith. His will was disputed by his widow Grace and his son-in-law Sir Thomas Monck.
